results.title: [KenRa Films Present Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 12. Car Racing] [excerpt]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This excerpt of Reel 12 of the film shows the family at a motor sport event held 1957 - 1959 Albert Park. A printed program reads ‘Second Day: 24th March 1957, Victorian Trophy Race, Organised by the Light Car Club of Australia’. The Light Car Club of Australia held motor races at Albert Park in between 1953 and 1958.

results.title: Hubby gets a Hobby
results.brief_description:
This short film, ‘Hubby Gets a Hobby’, was directed by Keith Greenwood and presented by KenRa Films (Kenneth Rankine). The black-and-white, silent film pokes fun at the amateur film community (which Rankine was a part of) with a story of a husband taking up amateur cinematography as a hobby, much to his wife’s displeasure. The film’s comedic narrative comes from the husband’s obsessive focus on cameras and film equipment as his wife objects to his new hobby (demonstrating now-outdated gender stereotypes). By the end of the film, he is vindicated by capturing footage of a building fire, which is used in a newsreel, and eventually his wife is seen taking up a camera as well.

The film is notable for its footage of early models of consumer cameras, including 16mm hand-wound Bell and Howell and Kodak cameras. It also includes footage of the Victorian Amateur Cine Society filming a production about Captain Cook outside Cook’s Cottage in Fitzroy Gardens. According to an opening sequence title cards, the film was awarded a prize by the Victorian Amateur Cine Society in 1947.

Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

results.title: Gaps
results.credit_line: Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney). The co-commission of ‘Gaps’ by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts.
results.brief_description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. ‘Gaps’ embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship - or ‘gaps’ - between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on ‘Gaps’ include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed ‘How to Feel’ 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period. Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.
results.description:

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period.

Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

results.credit_line_for_label: Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney). The co-commission of ‘Gaps’ by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts.

details.label: Measurements
display_values:
Duration: 35 mins, 7 seconds
The work does not need to be seen from beginning to end, viewers are invited to approach and engage with the work at any point throughout the duration.

production_dates.notes:
Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney).
David Rosetzky: Gaps will be a free exhibition at ACMI from 5 August 2014 to 8 February 2015.
The co-commission of Gaps by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts, its arts funding and advisory body.

results.title: The Woods
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, colour and audio
results.brief_description: The Woods is a video installation comprised of three documentaries on child film stars from the United States of America, Nigeria and India. ‘The Audition’ features Hollywood stars, ‘The Interview’ features Nollywood stars, and ‘The Rehearsal’ features Bollywood stars. The Woods was exhibited at ACMI as part of The Character exhibition in 2015.

results.title: An Interview with Glenn James
results.brief_description: When Glenn James’ fellow soldiers returned from service in Vietnam, they told him they finally understood what it was like to be Indigenous - you get treated like rubbish. Vietnam soldiers were brought home under the cover of night and at best ignored. For James, this was nothing new. As he talks about the plight of others that he has committed his life to helping, James provides some insight into an indomitable spirit, and how he has focused his energy into creating positive change for others.

results.title: Drat
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth O'Neill, Ann Shenfield, Robert Stephenson, Sarah Watt and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: A bunch of lab rats one night decide to break out and escape from their cages in the laboratory. One brain damaged rat, as a result of receiving shock-treatment, initially resists the call. This claymation reveals in its close yet another fiendish experiment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Elizabeth O’Neill, Ann Shenfield, Robert Stephenson, Sarah Watt and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television

results.title: All that is solid
results.brief_description: This is a speculative documentary on the subject of the future of Australia. It is conceived as a series of competing discourses with visionaries, politicians, media commentators and others, who are variously optimistic and pessimistic. Interviews are interspersed with symbolic, imaginative drama.

results.title: Nerida Anderson, 1939
results.creator_credit: Stephen Wallace, Bob Weis, Channel 0\28 and Generation Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Women of the sun (A)”.
Part Three of a series which presents events that occurred to four different aboriginal women at different periods in time. Set in 1939, this episode examines attempts by Nerida Anderson and her family to improve conditions on the Aboriginal Reserve where they live. Such attempts and displays of independence outrage the manager. He has Nerida and her family tried for treason. Realising a no-win situation, the entire population of the reserve pack their belongings and leave.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen Wallace, Bob Weis, Channel 0\28 and Generation Films

results.title: Maydina the shadow 1890's
results.creator_credit: David Stevens, Bob Weis, Channel 0\28 and Generation Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Women of the sun (A)”.
Part Two of a series which presents events that occurred to four different aboriginal women at different periods in time. This episode examines the life of Maydina and her daughter on a church mission run by a self-appointed guardian at the turn of the century. Follows her struggle to return to a tribal existence and her efforts to prevent her daughter being taken away from her by the mission guardian.

results.title: Beautiful lies: a film about Peter Carey
results.creator_credit: Don Featherstone, Australia Council and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Peter Carey is one of Australia’s most talented writers. All four of his published works have won major literary awards. This film, takes a journey through his life and work and looks at the way he transforms his native country into a bizarre land of nightmares and surreal comedy. Throughout the film, an interview with Peter Carey is interwoven with lavish dramatisation. An intriguing and illuminating film about a remarkable writer.
results.title_for_label: Beautiful lies: a film about Peter Carey
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Featherstone, Australia Council and Australian Film Commission
